column1: Any tear or hole in the membrane that surrounds the brain and spinal cord (dura) can allow the fluid that surrounds those organs to leak.
- Drainage of CSF from the ear (rarely) - Drainage of CSF from the nose (rarely)
Tests may include: - CT scan of the head with contrast dye - CT myelogram - MRI of the head or spine - Radioisotope test of the CSF to track the leakage
Drinking increased fluids, especially drinks with caffeine, can help slow or stop the leak and may help with headache pain.
Headache may be treated with pain relievers and fluids.
If the headache lasts longer than a week after a lumbar puncture, a procedure may be done to block the hole that may be leaking fluid.

Symptoms of infection (fever, chills, change in mental status) that occur after surgery on the brain or spinal cord or a lumbar puncture are a medical emergency and need to be treated with antibiotics.
Infections after surgery or trauma can lead to meningitis and serious complications, such as swelling of the brain.
Call your health care provider if: - You have a headache that gets worse when you sit up, especially if you have recently had a head injury, surgery, or childbirth involving epidural anesthesia.
- You have a moderate head injury, and then develop a headache that is worse when you sit up, or you have a thin, clear fluid draining from your nose or ear.
